Expectation1: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation1: The build is stalled because no one can proceed until their core module is complete
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A heat advisory is issued for the day and an elderly neighbor on the floor lives alone.
Story: I stared at the blinking cursor on my screen, the code for the core module half-finished. My team’s messages kept popping up—everyone was waiting on me. The project manager’s voice echoed in my head: “We can’t move forward until your part is done.” I knew the pressure was on; the whole build was stalled because of me. But then my phone buzzed with a city alert: a heat advisory. I remembered Mrs. Lee, my elderly neighbor, who lived alone just down the hall. She didn’t have air conditioning, and last summer she’d fainted from the heat. As a citizen, I felt responsible to check on her, maybe bring her some water or help her get to a cooling center. But if I left my desk now, the project would fall even further behind, and my team would be frustrated. My mind raced, torn between the urgent needs of my job and the quiet, pressing duty to my community. I sat frozen, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in, unsure which role I should answer first.
